abstract.value: The Margaret Strickland Papers feature the original typescripts of the English writer's biographical works, novels, plays, short stories, and short non-fiction pieces. In addition, this collection includes correspondence, diaries, hand-assembled illustrated magazines, photographs, and scrapbooks, dating from the 1880s to early 1960s.

p.value: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

Published citations should take the
following form:<lb/><lb/>
Identification of item,  date (if known); Margaret Strickland Papers; MSS 77; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
The collection was purchased from James Burmester in 1996.

Margaret had two sisters, both noted for their ability in drawing animals and staid, country scenes. Agnes Strickland is still remembered for her botanical illustrations, and Diana Mary (later Mrs. Mallet Veale) moved to Rhodesia and became well known for her illustrations of native life. Margaret's grandfather Thomas Strickland was the youngest brother of Agnes, Jane and Elizabeth Strickland, and Catharine Parr Traill. Agnes was the best known of the family and is remembered for her monumental work, <emph render="italic">The Lives of the Queens of England (1840-1848)</emph>. Several of Thomas' siblings, including Catharine and another brother, Samuel, immigrated to Canada, where Catherine wrote a number of books and novels, and Samuel founded the city of Lakeside.

Some of the most notable items in the collection are the twelve issues of "Illustrated Amateur Magazine," a small homemade publication Margaret created with her sisters Agnes, Diana Mary, and their friends in Bromley, Kent [now London], from 1897 - 1899. Despite their adolescent origins, these issues of "Illustrated Amateur Magazine" feature an especially acute knowledge of the publishing industry of the period, articles about current culture trends, and refined artwork in the form of original ink drawings and watercolor paintings.

Series I: CorrespondenceArrangement

These materials are arranged alphabetically by the name of the individual in contact with Strickland or the subject in conversation. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Scope and Contents

Series I: Correspondence pertains to Margaret Strickland’s personal and professional life, including correspondence from her closest friends, family, and colleagues in the publishing industry. This series features over 146 letters (over 660 pages) from Strickland’s sweetheart “Louis”, in addition to letters from her husband Richard Hugh Worley while he was on active service with the British Expeditionary Force and Kings Royal Rifle Corps during World War I.

Series II: ManuscriptsArrangement

These materials are arranged alphabetically by title or subject, then chronologically if applicable. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series and or subseries.

Scope and Content

Series II: Manuscripts documents Strickland's professional writing in the form of original typescript drafts with handwritten editing notation of over sixty-two titles, separated into four different subseries: A: Biographical, B: Novels, C: Plays, and D: Short Fiction & Non-Fiction. The final subseries, D: Short Fiction & Non-Fiction features small collections of Strickland's published work. "Five Animal Short Stories" [Box 4, Folder 20] and "Twelve Uncanny Stories" [Box 6, Folder 2] are handmade portfolio booklets of Strickland's stories that were published in The Blue Magazine & The Red Magazine, The Violet Magazine, and The Yellow Magazine, which were part of a small British popular fiction pulp format separated by subject and printed by the Amalgamated Press between July 1922 and December 1929. This series also comprises drafts of writing in various genres including adult mystery and romance fiction, children's adventure and detective fiction, historical fiction and creative non-fiction, as well as tests about animal care, food recipes and home remedy instructions.

Catharine Parr Traill (January 9, 1802 – August 28, 1899) was an English-Canadian author and naturalist who wrote children's and settler literature. Traill was the last surviving member of the Suffolk, England Stricklands. Many of Traill’s albums of plant collections are housed in the National Herbarium of Canada at the Canadian Museum of Nature in Ottawa, Ontario.

Series III: "Illustrated Amateur Magazine"Arrangement

These materials are arranged chronologically. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series and or subseries.

Scope and Contents

Series III: "Illustrated Amateur Magazine" features early examples Strickland sisters' art and writing. This series includes twelve issues of the title, a handmade publication Margaret created with her sisters Agnes, Diana Mary, and their friends in Bromley, Kent [now London], from 1897 - 1899. Despite their adolescent origins, these issues of "Illustrated Amateur Magazine" feature an especially acute knowledge of advertising and the magazine industry of the period. Contents include articles about current culture trends that range from art, bicycles, music, theater, to prize reader activities in the form of competitions and puzzles, to refined artwork in the form of ink drawings and watercolor paintings.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

These materials were treated by our conservation department for their fragile physical state, please handle with care.

Series IV: Diaries, Ephemera, ScrapbooksArrangement

These materials are arranged alphabetically by record format or type, then chronologically if applicable. In the case that a record includes more than one date expression, the listing will begin with its earliest. If a record is physically undated, approximate ranges are provided. These records are noted "undated" and followed by a "circa" estimate determined by the range represented in the same series.

Scope and Contents

Series IV: Diaries, Ephemera, Scrapbooks comprises bound and unbound memento materials, calendars, collected images and newsprint clippings of interest, collected and original poetry, correspondence, day to day domestic records, drawings and notation, event invitations that range from artistic performances to weddings, gardening awards from the Royal Horticultural Society, photographic portraits and postcards of loved ones, printed and published works, and traces of Strickland family history.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

These materials were treated by our conservation department for their fragile physical state, please handle with care.

These materials are arranged alphabetically by subject category, then chronologically if applicable. Scope and Contents

Series V: Photographs includes black and white prints of group portraits, mounted individuals' portraits, pocket and postcard portraits of men, women, children, and animals, interior design and exterior snapshots of estate gardens and grounds, and travel images. This series features a group portrait at Margaret Strickland and Richard Hugh Worley's wedding, as well as images from Richard's childhood and education at the University of Cambridge.
